title: 108_s553
content: The "Business Checking Freedom Act of 2003" allows all businesses to have interest-bearing transaction accounts. The "Business Checking Freedom Act of 2003" allows depository institutions to permit owners of interest-bearing accounts to make up to 24 transfers per month to another account in the same institution. The "Business Checking Freedom Act of 2003" allows owners of interest-bearing accounts to make up to 24 transfers per month to another account in the same institution, which will be considered a transaction account unless determined otherwise by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. SEC. 3. PAYMENT OF INTEREST ON RESERVES AT FEDERAL RESERVE BANKS. The amendment to the Federal Reserve Act allows depository institutions to earn interest on balances maintained at a Federal Reserve bank, with payments made quarterly at rates tied to short-term interest rates. The Board may establish regulations regarding these payments and distributions. The Board may regulate the payment of earnings, distribution to depository institutions, and responsibilities of institutions, Federal home loan banks, and the National Credit Union Administration Central. The National Credit Union Administration Central Liquidity Facility regulates the distribution of earnings to depository institutions, including trust companies. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to include trust companies, corporations, and foreign bank branches. Additionally, authorization for pass-through reserves for member banks is modified, and technical amendments are made to the Act. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to include trust companies, corporations, and foreign bank branches. Amendments include redesignating subparagraphs and modifying authorization for pass-through reserves for member banks. Technical changes are made to the Act. SEC. 4 amends the Federal Reserve Act to increase flexibility in setting reserve requirements. The ratio can now be not greater than 3 percent (including zero) and not less than zero. SEC. 5 involves the transfer of Federal Reserve surpluses. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow additional transfers from surplus funds to cover interest payments for fiscal years 2003 through 2007. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to transfer funds from surplus to cover interest payments for fiscal years 2003-2007, with the Federal Reserve Board determining the amount each bank pays annually. No replenishment of surplus funds is allowed during this period. During fiscal years 2003-2007, any excess amount in a Federal Reserve bank's surplus fund over 3 percent of member banks' capital and surplus must be transferred to the Treasury's general fund.
